page.title: 16Local History-South Kyme
page.content: South Kyme has always been an isolated settlement, surrounded by fenland. Its' river, the Kyme Eau flows to the Witham. The mediaeval tower is all that remains of a complete castle, begun in 14th. century, ruined in 18th.century. The south aisle of the church is also part of a much larger structure- a 12th. century priory for Black Canons. The name Kyme derives from the de Kymes, lords of the manor from Domes- day until 1338. The pub name, 'Hume Arms',(being changed to Simon d'kyme), comes from Abraham Hume, Duke of New- castle,who bought the village in 1748. The school (closed 1984), and many houses bear the initials of members of the Cust family, who had them built. They were the last lords of the manor, retaining links with the village until recently.
